title: Potential energy - energy stored stretching spring

content.question: One end of an ideal spring is attached to a wall and the other end to a block as shown. The block is initially at equilibrium at <math alttext="x equals 0 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mstyle></math>. A physics student determines that stretching the spring by moving the block from <math alttext="x equals 0 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="x equals 0.05 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.05</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mstyle></math> stores <math alttext="4.0 joules" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>4.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>J</mtext></mstyle></math> of energy in the block-spring system. How much additional energy is stored in the block-spring system after the block is moved from <math alttext="x equals 0.05 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.05</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="x equals 0.10 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.10</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mstyle></math>?

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
